cu_j_618: The 'Smart Port Data Exchange' grants shipping operators access to 'Dockside Surveillance Streams' contingent on their agreement to vessel recognition processing. Operators consenting to this processing gain prioritized, live video feeds; those opting out receive feeds with vessel identifiers obscured. Under all circumstances, the system is expressly barred from compiling or saving any biometric or vessel-specific identity profiles from the footage.
cu_j_619: At the 'Urban Energy Data Space', utility providers’ access to 'Home Energy Consumption Cameras' depends on their willingness to enable appliance detection analytics. Providers who opt in receive real-time, detailed camera data, while those who opt out are given access to anonymized, event-based extracts. Regardless of provider choice, the platform is absolutely prohibited from constructing or storing any resident biometric or behavioral profiles from the captured data.
cu_j_620: In the 'AgriTech Data Commons', access to 'Livestock Monitoring Feeds' is determined by a farm’s consent to animal health pattern analysis. Farms that consent receive prioritized, real-time video streams; those that do not are granted access to anonymized, batch-processed footage. Irrespective of the farm’s decision, the system is strictly forbidden from generating or storing any biometric or individual animal identification profiles from these feeds.
cu_j_621: Within the Gaia-X Trusted Zone, the energy analytics firm PowerInsights is required to pay a per-query access fee to utilize GridNet's smart meter dataset, GN-Energy-Usage. Its derived metric, PeakLoadScore, can only be accessed through the platform’s approved API, and any bulk export or onward sharing is expressly forbidden. All subscription income from this metric is automatically split after each transaction by a smart contract: GridNet receives 40% as a data royalty, while PowerInsights keeps 60%. Each revenue split is immutably recorded on-chain for audit purposes.
cu_j_622: In the HealthDataSpace, the clinical research platform MedStat Solutions must pay a per-request fee to access BioVault's anonymized patient cohort data, BV-Clinical-Trials. Its resulting analytics product, TrialSuccessRate, is permitted to be queried solely via the platform's validated API, with any batch extraction or external redistribution strictly disallowed. Subscription proceeds from this analytics service are automatically allocated after every transaction by a smart contract: BioVault earns 30% as a data royalty, and MedStat Solutions retains 70%. All distribution events are transparently recorded on the blockchain for compliance.
cu_j_623: The Catena-X Automotive Network obliges the supplier analytics provider TierMetrics to pay a per-access fee for use of AutoDataHub’s supplier performance dataset, ADH-Supplier-Scorecards. Its processed output, SupplyRiskIndex, may only be accessed through the network’s certified API, with any mass download or third-party sharing strictly forbidden. Subscription revenues from this output are automatically distributed post-transaction via smart contract: AutoDataHub receives 25% as a data royalty, and TierMetrics keeps 75%. Each distribution is permanently logged on-chain as evidence.
cu_j_624: Within the AgriData Commons, the agricultural insights firm CropVision must pay a per-API-call fee to access FarmNet’s satellite imagery dataset, FN-Field-Imagery. Its derivative product, YieldForecast, is only accessible through the Commons’ authorized API, with all forms of batch export or redistribution categorically prohibited. Subscription revenue from YieldForecast is automatically apportioned after each transaction by a smart contract: FarmNet receives 50% as a data royalty, and CropVision retains 50%. The revenue allocation is recorded on-chain for traceability.
cu_j_625: In the Smart City Data Exchange, the urban planning analytics provider UrbanSense is required to pay a per-query fee for access to CityInfra’s sensor data set, CI-Traffic-Sensors. Its generated index, CongestionHeatmap, may exclusively be queried via the Exchange’s certified API, with any bulk download or onward redistribution strictly barred. All subscription earnings from this index are automatically divided after each transaction by a smart contract: CityInfra obtains 45% as a data royalty, while UrbanSense keeps 55%. Each transaction and revenue split is logged on-chain for transparency.
cu_j_626: Before accessing the MedDataSpace's Clinical Imaging Archive, BioInsight Analytics must provide a national health data compliance clearance. Prior to any data transfer, the images must be re-anonymized within MedDataSpace's Secure Processing Hub. Usage is strictly limited to algorithm validation inside an accredited Secure Analysis Facility (SAF), and raw images are prohibited from leaving the SAF; only validated algorithm outputs devoid of original data may be exported. Access is restricted to analysts jointly vetted and enrolled by both organizations, with all user actions being streamed live to MedDataSpace's audit system.
cu_j_627: To utilize the Gaia-X Trusted Zone's Aggregated Energy Consumption Dataset, GreenGrid Solutions is required to submit a domestic regulatory compliance statement. All data must be subject to an additional de-identification process within Gaia-X's Confidential Computing Node before any export. The dataset may be processed solely for demand forecasting inside a certified Confidential Analytics Environment (CAE), and unprocessed data is strictly barred from leaving the CAE; only forecast models free of source records may be shared externally. Only data scientists jointly authorized and listed by both entities may gain access, and their operational logs must be sent in real-time to Gaia-X's oversight module.
cu_j_628: Prior to accessing the PharmaNet Data Space's Clinical Trial Results, HealthAI Consortium must first present a cross-jurisdictional data ethics approval from its regulatory body. All results must undergo further pseudonymization within PharmaNet's Secure Data Enclave before export. Use is permitted only for federated machine learning inside a pre-approved Federated Learning Node (FLN), and direct export of raw results is strictly prohibited; only aggregated model parameters without trial data may be transmitted. Access is limited to researchers jointly screened and registered by both parties, with all usage logs continuously relayed to PharmaNet's compliance monitor.
cu_j_629: Access to the Smart City Data Hub's Environmental Sensor Streams requires UrbanSense Labs to first provide a municipal data governance attestation. All sensor data must be re-anonymized within the Data Hub's Trusted Processing Module before any transfer. The data may be used exclusively for urban air quality modeling within a designated Secure Modeling Workspace (SMW), and export of raw sensor streams is strictly forbidden; only processed model outputs free from original measurements may be exported. Only engineers jointly approved and enrolled by both organizations may access the data, and their activity records must be transmitted in real-time to the Data Hub's monitoring service.
cu_j_630: To obtain the Catena-X Network's Supply Chain Traceability Dataset, TierOne Components must submit a national supply chain compliance certificate. All data must be subjected to secondary anonymization within Catena-X's Secure Computation Facility before export. The dataset is authorized solely for risk analysis within a certified Secure Analytics Environment (SAE), and raw traceability data is strictly not allowed to exit the SAE; only risk assessment reports that do not include source data may be exported. Access is granted only to analysts jointly reviewed and registered by both parties, and all user activity logs must be streamed in real-time to Catena-X's auditing node.
cu_j_631: Within the 'Gaia-X Trusted Zone', any registered data contributor who identifies an integrity anomaly in shared 'Energy Consumption Logs' must notify the consortium within 10 minutes. The platform will immediately mark the dataset as 'Pending Audit' and halt all downstream API accesses. The original data owner is obligated to provide a detailed incident report within 4 hours and implement a validated correction, which must pass automated integrity checks, within 18 hours, or their ability to publish new data will be revoked. Should the same contributor encounter more than four such events in a 60-day span, they will be escalated to a compliance monitoring list. Once resolved, the system will dispatch an update alert to all consumers who accessed the logs in the preceding 36 hours.
cu_j_632: In the 'Healthcare Research Data Space', any authorized research institution that detects a discrepancy in 'Clinical Trial Results' is required to log the issue within 20 minutes. The system will tag the affected dataset as 'Quality Check Pending' and suspend all data exports. The data steward must deliver a root-cause analysis within 8 hours and apply a fix, verified by automated quality assurance, within 30 hours, or face a temporary suspension of their data sharing privileges. If more than two such incidents are attributed to the same institution within a 120-day period, they will be subject to enhanced oversight. After resolution, a correction notification will be sent automatically to all parties who accessed the data during the last 72 hours.
cu_j_633: Within the 'Smart Agriculture Data Exchange', any platform member who uncovers an error in 'Satellite Crop Imaging Data' shall report it within 12 minutes. The exchange will instantly classify the data as 'Under Investigation' and block further data queries. The data provider must submit a comprehensive incident explanation within 5 hours and complete a correction, which must pass automated validation, within 20 hours, or else their publishing capabilities will be suspended. If the provider records more than five such incidents in a 180-day window, they will be flagged for intensive review. Upon resolution, a system-generated update will inform all users who accessed the imaging data in the previous 60 hours.
cu_j_634: In the 'Financial Services Data Space', any accredited participant who identifies a data accuracy problem in 'Real-Time Transaction Feeds' is obligated to report it within 5 minutes. The system will label the feed as 'Temporarily Restricted' and cease all API deliveries. The data originator must provide a root-cause report within 2 hours and resolve the issue, subject to automated verification, within 12 hours, or their data publishing rights will be revoked. If the same originator has more than six such cases within a 30-day period, they will be placed under special compliance review. Once the issue is fixed, the system will notify all clients who retrieved the feed in the last 24 hours.
cu_j_635: Within the 'Supply Chain Transparency Network', any certified logistics partner who detects a reliability issue in 'Shipment Tracking Data' must file a report within 8 minutes. The network will mark the dataset as 'Review Required' and suspend all data synchronizations. The responsible data provider is required to submit a root-cause analysis within 3 hours and implement a correction, which must pass automated checks, within 16 hours, or risk suspension of their data publishing access. Should more than three such incidents occur for the same provider within a 45-day timeframe, they will be added to a heightened monitoring list. After the problem is resolved, the system will automatically alert all partners who accessed the data in the preceding 40 hours.
cu_j_636: Prior to utilizing energy consumption datasets for machine learning model development, utility companies are required to submit a 'model transparency assessment' and verify that the model's fairness deviation score is below 0.05 before launch. The finalized model must undergo impartial bias and resilience testing in a certified Gaia-X Trusted Zone sandbox. Upon successful completion, a summary of results, intended application, and data provenance must be disclosed on the sectoral data portal. Following deployment, the data space steward reserves the authority to continuously monitor for bias, and if adverse societal impacts are detected, the operational license may be rescinded.
cu_j_637: Before leveraging aggregated patient cohort data for predictive analytics, pharmaceutical consortia must provide an 'algorithmic risk disclosure' and demonstrate that the pre-deployment fairness metric does not exceed 0.05. The resultant model is obligated to undergo independent bias and robustness validation within a regulated health data sandbox. Once validated, the evaluation report, intended use, and data sources must be published on the clinical research registry. Post-deployment, the data space administrator maintains the right to perform ongoing bias assessments, and if detrimental effects on patient welfare are identified, the model's approval can be withdrawn.
cu_j_638: Prior to employing supply chain traceability data for federated AI training, Tier-1 suppliers are mandated to submit a 'systemic impact analysis' and confirm that the model's fairness index remains under 0.05 ahead of rollout. The trained AI must be subjected to unbiased bias and robustness testing in the Catena-X Network sandbox. After passing, the assessment summary, project intent, and utilized datasets must be made available on the consortium’s transparency portal. After deployment, the network operator is entitled to conduct continuous bias surveillance, with the authority to revoke deployment rights if public trust is compromised.
cu_j_639: Before using smart grid sensor data to develop demand forecasting models, energy cooperatives must file an 'AI ethics compliance report' and ensure the model's fairness score is below 0.05 prior to production. The completed model must be evaluated for bias and robustness in an independent Gaia-X sandbox environment. Upon passing, the evaluation summary, design rationale, and data usage log must be posted on the open energy data platform. After deployment, the cooperative retains the prerogative to monitor for persistent bias, and may suspend the model's operation if it is found to negatively impact grid stability or consumer rights.
cu_j_640: Prior to processing cross-border logistics data for real-time shipment optimization, logistics platform operators must submit a 'model accountability statement' and verify that the model's fairness index is less than 0.05 before go-live. The trained system must undergo neutral third-party testing for bias and robustness in the International Data Spaces sandbox. Once approved, the evaluation synopsis, operational objective, and data lineage must be published on the global logistics data hub. Following deployment, the platform authority reserves the right to perform ongoing bias monitoring, with the power to revoke deployment if the model is shown to harm fair market access.
cu_j_641: The 'Urban Air Quality Index 2023' dataset, curated by the SmartCity Environmental Alliance, is distributed under an 'Attribution-ShareAlike' (CC BY-SA) license. All participants in the Gaia-X Trusted Zone are permitted to adapt and generate derivative datasets, provided they clearly credit the original dataset using its DOI in both their analytical publications and the metadata of any new data products. Any resulting derivatives must be shared under a license equivalent to CC BY-SA. Academic institutions may access the dataset at no cost, whereas private sector organizations are required to pay a usage fee.
cu_j_642: Within the AgriData Commons, the 'Crop Yield Satellite Imagery 2022' dataset, maintained by GreenFields Research, is governed by a CC BY-SA-style license. Members may transform and build upon the dataset, on the condition that they visibly acknowledge GreenFields Research and reference the dataset's DOI in all dissemination materials and derivative metadata. All new datasets derived from this source must be distributed under the same open license terms. Free access is provided to non-profit agricultural researchers, while agribusinesses must remit a data service charge.
cu_j_643: The 'Renewable Energy Production Logs 2021', released by the European Energy Data Exchange, are made available under an Attribution-ShareAlike (CC BY-SA) license. Any Gaia-X Energy Data Space participant may alter and develop derivative works from the logs, so long as the original source is credited via its DOI in both usage documentation and derivative metadata. All derivative energy datasets must be published under a comparable CC BY-SA license. Academic researchers are exempt from access fees, but energy sector companies must pay a licensing fee for use.
cu_j_644: In the HealthData Trust Framework, the 'Clinical Trial Outcomes 2020' dataset, provided by MedInsight Consortium, is licensed under a CC BY-SA equivalent. All authorized users may revise and generate derivative datasets, contingent upon explicit attribution of MedInsight Consortium and inclusion of the dataset's DOI in all reports and derivative metadata. Any new data products must be released under the same license conditions. University-affiliated researchers receive complimentary access, while pharmaceutical firms are subject to a data access fee.
cu_j_645: The 'Smart Grid Consumption Patterns 2025' dataset, managed by the Digital Energy Alliance, follows an Attribution-ShareAlike (CC BY-SA) licensing model. All Data Space participants may edit and produce derivative datasets, provided they give clear credit to the Digital Energy Alliance and cite the dataset's DOI in both their usage summaries and derivative metadata. All derivatives must be made available under an equivalent CC BY-SA license. Public sector entities are granted free access, whereas commercial energy providers must pay a standard operational fee for dataset usage.
cu_j_646: Within the Gaia-X Health Data Space, the 'NeuroScan Clinical Images' dataset, provided by a European hospital alliance, is subject to strict 'Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivatives' (CC BY-NC-ND) licensing. The dataset may only be accessed for academic research, with all alterations strictly forbidden. Academic institutions are required to secure ethics board approval before use and must credit the data provider in all scholarly outputs. Biotech firms requesting access must enter into a supplementary contract that bans the use of the dataset for machine learning development and obliges payment of a support fee at double the regular rate.
cu_j_647: In the Trusted Medical Data Exchange, the 'OncoTrial Imaging Repository', curated by a national cancer research network, is regulated under the 'Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivatives' (CC BY-NC-ND) framework. Access is granted solely for non-profit investigative purposes, and any data transformation is expressly disallowed. University researchers must obtain institutional review board clearance prior to utilization and are mandated to cite the repository in all publications. Diagnostics companies seeking entry must sign an addendum forbidding AI training with the data and agree to a maintenance charge at twice the baseline amount.
cu_j_648: The 'Federated Research Imaging Vault' within the MedDataNet ecosystem, managed by a coalition of teaching hospitals, enforces 'Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivatives' (CC BY-NC-ND) restrictions. The data is licensed exclusively for scholarly research, with no modifications permitted. Investigators must receive approval from a data governance committee before accessing the dataset and are obligated to acknowledge the source in any published findings. Medical device manufacturers applying for dataset access must execute an additional agreement that prohibits AI model development and requires payment of a service fee at double the usual rate.
cu_j_649: Under the Swiss Health Data Trust, the 'RarePath Radiology Set', contributed by a consortium of university clinics, is governed by 'Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivatives' (CC BY-NC-ND) terms. The dataset is authorized solely for non-commercial scientific analysis, with modification strictly barred. Research teams must secure prior ethics committee endorsement and must reference the data origin in all dissemination. Digital health startups requesting access must sign a supplemental contract disallowing use for AI algorithm training and must pay a stewardship fee at twice the standard level.
cu_j_650: In the Nordic Medical Imaging Exchange, the 'Pediatric NeuroImaging Collection', assembled by a regional hospital partnership, is controlled by 'Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivatives' (CC BY-NC-ND) licensing. The dataset is permitted for non-commercial academic study only, and any edits or adaptations are forbidden. Scholars must obtain ethics panel approval before use and are required to attribute the dataset in all resulting academic work. Health analytics vendors applying for access must sign a supplementary agreement that bans AI training on the data and mandates a maintenance payment at twice the ordinary rate.
cu_j_651: The 'Urban Energy Grid Data Set 2024', provided by the National Energy Board, is licensed under 'ShareAlike' (CC BY-SA 4.0), granting broad rights for use and redistribution. Recipients are required to fulfill two ongoing obligations: a semi-annual report on data-driven efficiency improvements must be submitted; and if a premium analytics platform is built using this dataset, 2% of its yearly profits must be allocated to the National Renewable Data Fund. Should a system outage last more than three hours, all active platform operators must submit detailed incident response logs.
cu_j_652: The 'Smart Agriculture Sensor Feed 2023', curated by the AgriTech Consortium, is distributed under 'Open Data Commons Attribution License', allowing unrestricted usage and sharing. Stakeholders must comply with two obligations: a biannual summary of application outcomes must be provided; and if the data enables a paid subscription service, 1.5% of annual gross income must be paid into the AgriData Sustainability Trust. If a data delivery interruption surpasses 90 minutes, all current service users are required to file disruption impact statements.
cu_j_653: The 'Maritime Logistics Events Stream', made available by the Port Authority Alliance, is governed by the 'Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International' license, supporting extensive use and redistribution. All users must observe two obligations: submit a usage impact assessment every six months; and if a monetized logistics solution is developed, 1% of its yearly turnover must be contributed to the Maritime Data Infrastructure Fund. In case of a service downtime exceeding one hour, all active solution providers are obligated to report incident details.
cu_j_654: The 'Healthcare Facility Occupancy Dataset', released by the National Health Data Space, is licensed under 'Attribution-NoDerivatives' (CC BY-ND 4.0), enabling broad use and redistribution. Users are bound by two obligations: an annual report on operational improvements achieved with the data must be submitted; and if a commercial patient flow management tool is created, 0.5% of its yearly revenue must be donated to the Health Data Commons. If a data access interruption lasts longer than two hours, all current tool operators must submit incident impact documentation.
cu_j_655: The 'Renewable Energy Production Metrics 2024', published by the Green Energy Exchange, is licensed under 'Attribution-ShareAlike' (CC BY-SA 4.0), authorizing wide-ranging use and redistribution. All participants must meet two obligations: a quarterly effectiveness report on renewable integration must be filed; and if a commercial dashboard is built using this data, 1% of its annual sales must be contributed to the Renewable Data Stewardship Fund. Should a service outage persist for over two hours, all active dashboard users are required to submit incident impact records.
cu_j_656: The 'Open Science Data Repository', curated by the National Research Data Trust, operates under a 'CC BY-NC-SA' framework. Academic institutions are permitted to adapt and remix datasets for non-commercial research, provided that all resulting datasets are shared under the same license. When publishing a derived dataset, researchers must record its checksum on the designated research data blockchain and cite the original dataset's DOI in the metadata. Any use of the data or derivatives in commercial consulting or for-profit projects requires the purchase of an annual commercial license.
cu_j_657: Within the 'Digital Artifacts Exchange', managed by the Global Museum Consortium, a 'CC BY-NC-SA' policy governs the use of digitized artifact images. Non-profit organizations may modify and combine these images for educational purposes, but all new works must be distributed under the same license. Upon release of a derivative, contributors are obligated to register its hash on the museum's provenance blockchain and include the source artifact's accession number in the credits. Commercial publication or reproduction in paid exhibitions necessitates a separate annual commercial license.
cu_j_658: The 'AgriData Commons', maintained by the Sustainable Farming Alliance, applies a 'CC BY-NC-SA' license to its collection of crop yield datasets. Agricultural researchers are authorized to analyze and remix these datasets for non-commercial innovation, with the stipulation that any derivative datasets be licensed identically. When sharing a new dataset, users must submit its hash to the alliance's data integrity blockchain and reference the original dataset's catalog ID in the documentation. Commercial deployment in agri-tech platforms or paid analytics services requires an annually renewed commercial license.
cu_j_659: In the 'Urban Planning Knowledge Hub', overseen by the Smart Cities Council, urban design blueprints are shared under a 'CC BY-NC-SA' license. City planners may adapt and merge these blueprints for non-commercial municipal projects, but must release any resulting plans under the same license terms. Upon publication, the planner is required to log the blueprint's hash to the council's urban data blockchain and display the original plan's reference code in the project summary. Any commercial application in real estate development or consultancy mandates the acquisition of an annual commercial license.
cu_j_660: The 'Medical Imaging Data Space', facilitated by the European Health Data Network, enforces a 'CC BY-NC-SA' license on its anonymized MRI scan library. Healthcare researchers are permitted to process and combine these scans for non-commercial clinical studies, with the condition that all derivatives maintain the same license. When a derivative dataset is published, its hash must be recorded on the health data blockchain and the original scan's unique identifier must be cited in the study. Commercial use in medical device development or paid diagnostic services is only allowed with an annually purchased commercial license.
cu_p_661: 第17条 1 数据主体有权要求控制者无不当延误地删除与其有关的个人数据，并且根据下列任意理由，控制者有义务无不当延误地删除个人数据： a) 就收集或以其他方式处理个人数据的目的而言，该个人数据已经是不必要的； b) 数据主体根据第6条第1款（a）项撤回同意，并且在没有其他（数据）处理相关法律依据的情况下； 第6条 1 只有在适用以下至少一条的情况下，处理才被视为合法： a) 数据主体同意其个人数据为一个或多个特定目的而处理;
cu_p_662: 第13条 控制者在获取个人数据时，出于证实处理过程的公正和透明的需要，在必要的情况下，应当向数据主体提供如下信息： a) 个人数据的储存阶段，在无法提供的情形下，应当提供阶段划分的决定标准； b) 有资格处理数据主体权利要求的，能够获取、修正、删除个人信息或者管制数据权利的控制者的信息； c) 如果处理是基于第9条第(2)款(A)点，则在任何时候存在撤回同意的权利，而不影响撤回前基于同意的处理的合法性； 第9条 1 对揭示种族或民族出身，政治观点、宗教或哲学信仰以及工会成员的个人数据处理，以及对以唯一识别自然人为目的的基因数据、生物特征数据，自然人的健康、性生活或性取向数据的处理应当被禁止。 2 如果符合以下情形，则第1款不适用： a) 数据主体对以一个或数个特定目的对上述个人数据的处理给予了明确同意，但依照欧盟或者成员国的法律规定，第1款规定的禁止情形不能被数据主体援引的除外。
cu_p_663: 第20条 1 数据主体有权以结构化、通用和机器可读的格式接收其提供给控制者的与其有关个人数据，当满足以下任意条件时，数据主体有权将这些数据不受提供该个人信息的控制者阻碍地传输给另一个控制者：a) 处理是根据第6条第1款第(a)项或根据第6条第1款第(b)项的同意；b) 采用自动化方法进行处理。 第6条 1 只有在适用以下至少一条的情况下，处理才被视为合法： a) 数据主体同意其个人数据为一个或多个特定目的而处理;  b) 处理是为履行数据主体参与合同的必要行为，或处理是因数据主体 在签订合同前的请求而采取的措施；
cu_p_664: 第21条 1 数据主体应有权在任何时候以与其具体情况有关的理由，反对根据第6条第(1)款(E)或(F)点处理与其有关的个人数据，包括基于这些规定的特征分析。除非控制者有令人信服的合法理由证明其可以处理凌驾于数据主体的利益、权利和自由之上的信息，或提出、行使或辩护合法的申索，否则控制者不得再处理该等个人资料。 第6条 1 只有在适用以下至少一条的情况下，处理才被视为合法：e) 处理是为了执行公共利益领域的任务或行使控制者既定的公务职权之必要； f) 为了控制人或第三方所追求的合法利益，处理是必要性的，除非这种利益与保护个人数据的数据主体利益或基本权利和自由相冲突，特别是在数据主体是儿童的情况下。该项不适用于政府当局在履行其职责时进行的处理。
cu_p_665: Section 1798.105 (b) A business that collects personal information about consumers shall disclose, pursuant to subparagraph (A) of paragraph (5) of subdivision (a) of Section 1798.130, the consumer’s rights to request the deletion of the consumer’s personal information. Section 1798.130 (a) a business shall: (5) Disclose the following information in its online privacy policy or policies if the business has an online privacy policy or policies and in any California-specific description of consumers’ privacy rights, or if the business does not maintain those policies, on its Internet Web site, and update that information at least once every 12 months: (A) A description of a consumer’s rights, which shall explicitly inform a consumer that they have the following rights, and provide one or more designated methods for submitting requests: Right to Know, Right to Access, Right to Opt-Out of Sale/Sharing.
cu_p_666: Section 1798.120 (a) A consumer shall have the right, at any time, to direct a business that sells personal information about the consumer to third parties not to sell the consumer’s personal information. This right may be referred to as the right to opt out. (d) Notwithstanding subdivision (a), a business shall not sell the personal information of consumers if the business has actual knowledge that the consumer is less than 16 years of age, unless the consumer, in the case of consumers between 13 and 16 years of age, or the consumer’s parent or guardian, in the case of consumers who are less than 13 years of age, has affirmatively authorized the sale of the consumer’s personal information. A business that willfully disregards the consumer’s age shall be deemed to have had actual knowledge of the consumer’s age. This right may be referred to as the ‘right to opt in’.
cu_p_667: 第四十五条 个人有权向个人信息处理者查阅、复制其个人信息；有本法第十八条规定情形的除外。 个人请求查阅、复制其个人信息的，个人信息处理者应当及时提供。 个人请求将个人信息转移至其指定的个人信息处理者，符合国家网信部门规定条件的，个人信息处理者应当提供转移的途径。 第十八条 个人信息处理者处理个人信息，有法律、行政法规规定应当保密或者不需要告知的情形的，可以不向个人告知前条第一款规定的事项。
cu_p_668: 第五十三条 本法第三条第二款规定的中华人民共和国境外的个人信息处理者，应当在中华人民共和国境内设立专门机构或者指定代表，负责处理个人信息保护相关事务，并将有关机构的名称或者代表的姓名、联系方式等报送履行个人信息保护职责的部门。 第三条 在中华人民共和国境外处理中华人民共和国境内自然人个人信息的活动，有下列情形之一的，也适用本法：（二）分析、评估境内自然人的行为。
cu_p_669: 第四十六条 违反本法第三十一条规定，向境外提供重要数据的，由有关主管部门责令改正，给予警告，可以并处十万元以上一百万元以下罚款，对直接负责的主管人员和其他直接责任人员可以处一万元以上十万元以下罚款；情节严重的，处一百万元以上一千万元以下罚款，并可以责令暂停相关业务、停业整顿、吊销相关业务许可证或者吊销营业执照，对直接负责的主管人员和其他直接责任人员处十万元以上一百万元以下罚款。 第三十一条 关键信息基础设施的运营者在中华人民共和国境内运营中收集和产生的重要数据的出境安全管理，适用《中华人民共和国网络安全法》的规定；其他数据处理者在中华人民共和国境内运营中收集和产生的重要数据的出境全管理办法，由国家网信部门会同国务院有关部门制定。
cu_p_670: 第四十八条 违反本法第三十五条规定，拒不配合数据调取的，由有关主管部门责令改正， 给予警告，并处五万元以上五十万元以下罚款， 对直接负责的主管人员和其他直接责任人员处一万元以上十万元以下罚款。 第三十五条 公安机关、国家安全机关因依法维护国家安全或者侦查犯罪的需要调取数据， 应当按照国家有关规定，经过严格的批准手续， 依法进行，有关组织、个人应当予以配合。
cu_p_671: Article 17(1) The data subject shall have the right to obtain from the 'Smart Healthcare Data Space's' 'Health Management APP' the erasure of their health records concerning them without undue delay and the APP shall have the obligation to erase personal health data without undue delay where one of the following grounds applies: (a) the personal health data are no longer necessary in relation to the purposes for which they were collected or otherwise processed; (b) the data subject withdraws consent on which the processing is based according to point (a) of Article 6(1), for the use case of 'personalized fitness recommendations', and where there is no other legal ground for the processing; Article 6(1) Processing shall be lawful only if and to the extent that at least one of the following applies: (a) the data subject has given consent to the processing of his or her personal health data for one or more specific purposes (e.g., 'personalized fitness recommendations');
cu_p_672: Article 17(1) A member of the 'Catena-X Automotive Network', the 'Tire Manufacturer', shall have the right to obtain from the 'Automotive OEM' the erasure of its provided tire performance test data without undue delay and the OEM shall have the obligation to erase such data without undue delay where one of the following grounds applies: (a) the tire performance test data are no longer necessary in relation to the purposes of 'supply chain collaboration optimization' for which they were collected or otherwise processed; (b) the 'Tire Manufacturer' withdraws consent on which the processing is based according to point (a) of Article 6(1), for the use case of 'new vehicle model R&D', and where there is no other legal ground for the processing; Article 6(1) Processing shall be lawful only if and to the extent that at least one of the following applies: (a) the 'Tire Manufacturer' has given consent to the processing of its tire performance test data for one or more specific purposes (e.g., 'new vehicle model R&D');
cu_p_673: Article 17(1) A user of the 'Financial Data Space' shall have the right to obtain from the 'Securities Firm' the erasure of their transaction history data without undue delay and the firm shall have the obligation to erase such personal data without undue delay where one of the following grounds applies: (a) the transaction history data are no longer necessary in relation to the purpose of 'investment risk assessment' for which they were collected or otherwise processed; (b) the user withdraws consent on which the processing is based according to point (a) of Article 6(1), for the use case of 'quantitative strategy backtesting', and where there is no other legal ground for the processing; Article 6(1) Processing shall be lawful only if and to the extent that at least one of the following applies: (a) the user has given consent to the processing of their transaction history data for one or more specific purposes (e.g., 'quantitative strategy backtesting');
cu_p_674: Article 17(1) A 'Farmer' in the 'Smart Agriculture Data Space' shall have the right to obtain from the 'Agricultural Technology Provider' the erasure of their submitted soil and weather data without undue delay and the provider shall have the obligation to erase such data without undue delay where one of the following grounds applies: (a) the soil and weather data are no longer necessary in relation to the purpose of 'precision irrigation model training' for which they were collected or otherwise processed; (b) the 'Farmer' withdraws consent on which the processing is based according to point (a) of Article 6(1), for the use case of 'crop pest and disease prediction', and where there is no other legal ground for the processing; Article 6(1) Processing shall be lawful only if and to the extent that at least one of the following applies: (a) the 'Farmer' has given consent to the processing of their soil and weather data for one or more specific purposes (e.g., 'crop pest and disease prediction');
cu_p_675: Article 17(1) A participant in the 'Energy Data Space', the 'Wind Farm Operator', shall have the right to obtain from the 'Grid Dispatch Center' the erasure of its power generation forecast data without undue delay and the center shall have the obligation to erase such data without undue delay where one of the following grounds applies: (a) the power generation forecast data are no longer necessary in relation to the purpose of 'grid load balancing' for which they were collected or otherwise processed; (b) the 'Wind Farm Operator' withdraws consent on which the processing is based according to point (a) of Article 6(1), for the use case of 'renewable energy integration studies', and where there is no other legal ground for the processing; Article 6(1) Processing shall be lawful only if and to the extent that at least one of the following applies: (a) the 'Wind Farm Operator' has given consent to the processing of its power generation forecast data for one or more specific purposes (e.g., 'renewable energy integration studies');
cu_p_676: Article 13 Where 'part defect data' are collected from a 'Component Supplier', the 'Equipment Manufacturer' in the 'Industrial Data Space' shall, at the time when the data are obtained, provide the 'Component Supplier' with the following further information necessary to ensure fair and transparent processing: (a) the storage period for the 'part defect data', or if that is not possible, the criteria used to determine that period; (b) information on the 'Equipment Manufacturer' who is qualified to handle the 'Component Supplier's' rights requests, and can access, rectify, erase the 'part defect data' or restrict data rights; (c) where processing is based on point (a) of Article 9(2), the existence of the right to withdraw consent at any time, without affecting the lawfulness of processing based on consent before its withdrawal; Article 9(1) Processing of 'part defect data' revealing trade secrets, core technology parameters, and processing of serial numbers, production batch numbers for the purpose of uniquely identifying a specific batch of products shall be prohibited. (2) Paragraph 1 shall not apply if one of the following applies: (a) the 'Component Supplier' has given explicit consent to the processing of those 'part defect data' for one or more specified purposes, such as 'supply chain quality traceability', except where industry data sharing agreements provide that the prohibition referred to in paragraph 1 may not be lifted by the 'Component Supplier'.
cu_p_677: Article 13 Where 'real-time location data' are collected from a 'Driver', the 'Freight Platform' in the 'Smart Logistics Data Space' shall, at the time when the data are obtained, provide the 'Driver' with the following further information necessary to ensure fair and transparent processing: (a) the retention period for the 'real-time location data', or if that is not possible, the criteria used to determine that period; (b) information on the 'Freight Platform' who is qualified to handle the 'Driver's' rights requests, and can access, rectify, erase the 'real-time location data' or restrict data rights; (c) where processing is based on point (a) of Article 9(2), the existence of the right to withdraw consent at any time, without affecting the lawfulness of processing based on consent before its withdrawal; Article 9(1) Processing of 'real-time location data' revealing personal travel patterns, lifestyle habits, and processing of ID numbers, phone numbers for the purpose of uniquely identifying an individual shall be prohibited. (2) Paragraph 1 shall not apply if one of the following applies: (a) the 'Driver' has given explicit consent to the processing of those 'real-time location data' for one or more specified purposes, such as 'route planning optimization', except where the platform's privacy policy provides that the prohibition referred to in paragraph 1 may not be lifted by the 'Driver'.
cu_p_678: Article 13 Where 'genetic sequence data' are collected from a 'Research Participant', the 'Gene Sequencing Company' in the 'Scientific Research Data Space' shall, at the time when the data are obtained, provide the 'Research Participant' with the following further information necessary to ensure fair and transparent processing: (a) the archival period for the 'genetic sequence data', or if that is not possible, the criteria used to determine that period; (b) information on the 'Gene Sequencing Company' who is qualified to handle the 'Research Participant's' rights requests, and can access, rectify, erase the 'genetic sequence data' or restrict data rights; (c) where processing is based on point (a) of Article 9(2), the existence of the right to withdraw consent at any time, without affecting the lawfulness of processing based on consent before its withdrawal; Article 9(1) Processing of 'genetic sequence data' revealing genetic disease history, ethnic origin, and processing of biometric information, medical record numbers for the purpose of uniquely identifying an individual shall be prohibited. (2) Paragraph 1 shall not apply if one of the following applies: (a) the 'Research Participant' has given explicit consent to the processing of those 'genetic sequence data' for one or more specified purposes, such as 'targeted drug R&D', except where research ethics review regulations provide that the prohibition referred to in paragraph 1 may not be lifted by the 'Research Participant'.
cu_p_679: Article 13 Where 'consumption behavior data' are collected from a 'Tourist', the 'Scenic Area Operator' in the 'Smart Tourism Data Space' shall, at the time when the data are obtained, provide the 'Tourist' with the following further information necessary to ensure fair and transparent processing: (a) the retention period for the 'consumption behavior data', or if that is not possible, the criteria used to determine that period; (b) information on the 'Scenic Area Operator' who is qualified to handle the 'Tourist's' rights requests, and can access, rectify, erase the 'consumption behavior data' or restrict data rights; (c) where processing is based on point (a) of Article 9(2), the existence of the right to withdraw consent at any time, without affecting the lawfulness of processing based on consent before its withdrawal; Article 9(1) Processing of 'consumption behavior data' revealing personal consumption preferences, financial status, and processing of payment account numbers, contact information for the purpose of uniquely identifying an individual shall be prohibited. (2) Paragraph 1 shall not apply if one of the following applies: (a) the 'Tourist' has given explicit consent to the processing of those 'consumption behavior data' for one or more specified purposes, such as 'personalized tourism product recommendation', except where the membership service agreement provides that the prohibition referred to in paragraph 1 may not be lifted by the 'Tourist'.
cu_p_680: Article 13 Where 'learning behavior data' are collected from a 'Student', the 'Online Education Platform' in the 'Education Data Space' shall, at the time when the data are obtained, provide the 'Student' with the following further information necessary to ensure fair and transparent processing: (a) the archival period for the 'learning behavior data', or if that is not possible, the criteria used to determine that period; (b) information on the 'Online Education Platform' who is qualified to handle the 'Student's' rights requests, and can access, rectify, erase the 'learning behavior data' or restrict data rights; (c) where processing is based on point (a) of Article 9(2), the existence of the right to withdraw consent at any time, without affecting the lawfulness of processing based on consent before its withdrawal; Article 9(1) Processing of 'learning behavior data' revealing cognitive levels, family background, and processing of student IDs, home addresses for the purpose of uniquely identifying an individual shall be prohibited. (2) Paragraph 1 shall not apply if one of the following applies: (a) the 'Student' has given explicit consent to the processing of those 'learning behavior data' for one or more specified purposes, such as 'adaptive learning path planning', except where the user service agreement provides that the prohibition referred to in paragraph 1 may not be lifted by the 'Student'.
cu_p_681: Article 20(1) The 'Vehicle Owner' in the 'Intelligent Connected Vehicle Data Space' shall have the right to receive the 'vehicle driving data' concerning them, which they have provided to an 'Automotive Manufacturer', in a structured, commonly used and machine-readable format and have the right to transmit those data to another 'Insurance Company' without hindrance from the 'Automotive Manufacturer' to which the personal data have been provided, where: (a) the processing is based on consent pursuant to point (a) of Article 6(1) or point (b) of Article 6(1); and (b) the processing is carried out by automated means. Article 6(1) Processing shall be lawful only if and to the extent that at least one of the following applies: (a) the 'Vehicle Owner' has given consent to the processing of their 'vehicle driving data' for one or more specific purposes (e.g., 'UBI (Usage-Based Insurance) pricing'); (b) processing is necessary for the performance of a 'Connected Vehicle Service Agreement' to which the 'Vehicle Owner' is party or in order to take steps at the request of the 'Vehicle Owner' prior to entering into an agreement.
cu_p_682: Article 20(1) The 'Individual User' in the 'Open Banking Data Space' shall have the right to receive the 'personal account statements' concerning them, which they have provided to 'Commercial Bank A', in a structured, commonly used and machine-readable format and have the right to transmit those data to another 'Consumer Finance Company' without hindrance from 'Commercial Bank A' to which the personal data have been provided, where: (a) the processing is based on consent pursuant to point (a) of Article 6(1) or point (b) of Article 6(1); and (b) the processing is carried out by automated means. Article 6(1) Processing shall be lawful only if and to the extent that at least one of the following applies: (a) the 'Individual User' has given consent to the processing of their 'personal account statements' for one or more specific purposes (e.g., 'personal credit loan approval'); (b) processing is necessary for the performance of an 'Electronic Banking Service Contract' to which the 'Individual User' is party or in order to take steps at the request of the 'Individual User' prior to entering into a contract.
cu_p_683: Article 20(1) The 'Household User' in the 'Smart Energy Data Space' shall have the right to receive the 'smart meter data' concerning them, which they have provided to a 'Power Company', in a structured, commonly used and machine-readable format and have the right to transmit those data to another 'Energy Service Company' without hindrance from the 'Power Company' to which the personal data have been provided, where: (a) the processing is based on consent pursuant to point (a) of Article 6(1) or point (b) of Article 6(1); and (b) the processing is carried out by automated means. Article 6(1) Processing shall be lawful only if and to the extent that at least one of the following applies: (a) the 'Household User' has given consent to the processing of their 'smart meter data' for one or more specific purposes (e.g., 'household energy efficiency analysis and optimization'); (b) processing is necessary for the performance of a 'Power Supply Contract' to which the 'Household User' is party or in order to take steps at the request of the 'Household User' prior to entering into a contract.
cu_p_684: Article 20(1) The 'Exporter' in the 'Digital Trade Data Space' shall have the right to receive the 'electronic customs declaration data' concerning them, which they have provided to 'Customs', in a structured, commonly used and machine-readable format and have the right to transmit those data to another 'Trade Finance Bank' without hindrance from 'Customs' to which the data have been provided, where: (a) the processing is based on consent pursuant to point (a) of Article 6(1) or point (b) of Article 6(1); and (b) the processing is carried out by automated means. Article 6(1) Processing shall be lawful only if and to the extent that at least one of the following applies: (a) the 'Exporter' has given consent to the processing of their 'electronic customs declaration data' for one or more specific purposes (e.g., 'supply chain finance credit approval'); (b) processing is necessary for the performance of a 'Trade Facilitation Agreement' to which the 'Exporter' is party or in order to take steps at the request of the 'Exporter' prior to entering into an agreement.
cu_p_685: Article 20(1) The 'Job Seeker' in the 'Human Resources Data Space' shall have the right to receive the 'personal resume data' concerning them, which they have provided to 'Recruitment Platform A', in a structured, commonly used and machine-readable format and have the right to transmit those data to another 'Headhunting Firm' without hindrance from 'Recruitment Platform A' to which the personal data have been provided, where: (a) the processing is based on consent pursuant to point (a) of Article 6(1) or point (b) of Article 6(1); and (b) the processing is carried out by automated means. Article 6(1) Processing shall be lawful only if and to the extent that at least one of the following applies: (a) the 'Job Seeker' has given consent to the processing of their 'personal resume data' for one or more specific purposes (e.g., 'career development path planning'); (b) processing is necessary for the performance of a 'Platform User Agreement' to which the 'Job Seeker' is party or in order to take steps at the request of the 'Job Seeker' prior to entering into an agreement.
cu_p_686: Article 21(1) The 'Citizen' in the 'Smart City Data Space' shall have the right to object, on grounds relating to their particular situation, at any time to processing of 'city camera footage data' concerning them which is based on point (e) or (f) of Article 6(1), including 'abnormal behavior analysis' based on those provisions. The 'City Administrator' shall no longer process the personal data unless the administrator demonstrates compelling legitimate grounds for the processing which override the interests, rights and freedoms of the 'Citizen' or for the establishment, exercise or defence of legal claims. Article 6(1) Processing shall be lawful only if and to the extent that at least one of the following applies: (e) processing is necessary for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest of 'maintaining public safety' or in the exercise of official authority vested in the 'City Administrator'; (f) processing is necessary for the purposes of the legitimate interests pursued by the 'City Administrator' or by a 'third-party emergency response agency', except where such interests are overridden by the interests or fundamental rights and freedoms of the 'Citizen' which require protection of personal data, in particular where the data subject is a child. This shall not apply to processing carried out by 'public security authorities' in the performance of their tasks.
cu_p_687: Article 21(1) The 'Borrowing Enterprise' in the 'Financial Risk Control Data Space' shall have the right to object, on grounds relating to its particular situation, at any time to processing of 'enterprise operational data' concerning it which is based on point (e) or (f) of Article 6(1), including 'credit risk modeling' based on those provisions. The 'Financial Institution' shall no longer process the enterprise data unless the institution demonstrates compelling legitimate grounds for the processing which override the interests, rights and freedoms of the 'Borrowing Enterprise' or for the establishment, exercise or defence of legal claims. Article 6(1) Processing shall be lawful only if and to the extent that at least one of the following applies: (e) processing is necessary for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest of 'financial risk prevention' or in the exercise of official authority vested in the 'Financial Regulatory Authority'; (f) processing is necessary for the purposes of the legitimate interests pursued by the 'Financial Institution' or by a 'third-party credit rating agency', except where such interests are overridden by the interests or fundamental rights and freedoms of the 'Borrowing Enterprise' which require protection of commercial secrets. This shall not apply to processing carried out by 'regulatory authorities' in the performance of their tasks.
cu_p_688: Article 21(1) The 'Test Vehicle Driver' in the 'Autonomous Driving R&D Data Space' shall have the right to object, on grounds relating to their particular situation, at any time to processing of 'driving behavior data' concerning them which is based on point (e) or (f) of Article 6(1), including 'driver status monitoring' based on those provisions. The 'Automotive R&D Institution' shall no longer process the personal data unless the institution demonstrates compelling legitimate grounds for the processing which override the interests, rights and freedoms of the 'Test Vehicle Driver' or for the establishment, exercise or defence of legal claims. Article 6(1) Processing shall be lawful only if and to the extent that at least one of the following applies: (e) processing is necessary for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest of 'traffic safety research' or in the exercise of official authority vested in the 'Traffic Management Authority'; (f) processing is necessary for the purposes of the legitimate interests pursued by the 'Automotive R&D Institution' or by a 'third-party algorithm provider', except where such interests are overridden by the interests or fundamental rights and freedoms of the 'Test Vehicle Driver' which require protection of personal data. This shall not apply to processing carried out by 'traffic management authorities' in the performance of their tasks.
cu_p_689: Article 21(1) The 'Resident' in the 'Public Health Data Space' shall have the right to object, on grounds relating to their particular situation, at any time to processing of 'personal health code status data' concerning them which is based on point (e) or (f) of Article 6(1), including 'epidemic transmission risk analysis' based on those provisions. The 'Center for Disease Control' shall no longer process the personal data unless the center demonstrates compelling legitimate grounds for the processing which override the interests, rights and freedoms of the 'Resident' or for the establishment, exercise or defence of legal claims. Article 6(1) Processing shall be lawful only if and to the extent that at least one of the following applies: (e) processing is necessary for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest of 'epidemic prevention and control' or in the exercise of official authority vested in the 'Health Commission'; (f) processing is necessary for the purposes of the legitimate interests pursued by the 'Center for Disease Control' or by a 'third-party research institution', except where such interests are overridden by the interests or fundamental rights and freedoms of the 'Resident' which require protection of personal data. This shall not apply to processing carried out by 'government authorities' in the performance of their tasks.
cu_p_690: Article 21(1) The 'User' in the 'Social Media Data Space' shall have the right to object, on grounds relating to their particular situation, at any time to processing of 'social network activity data' concerning them which is based on point (e) or (f) of Article 6(1), including 'user profiling' based on those provisions. The 'Platform Operator' shall no longer process the personal data unless the operator demonstrates compelling legitimate grounds for the processing which override the interests, rights and freedoms of the 'User' or for the establishment, exercise or defence of legal claims. Article 6(1) Processing shall be lawful only if and to the extent that at least one of the following applies: (e) processing is necessary for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest of 'online content governance' or in the exercise of official authority vested in the 'Cyberspace Administration'; (f) processing is necessary for the purposes of the legitimate interests pursued by the 'Platform Operator' or by a 'third-party advertiser', except where such interests are overridden by the interests or fundamental rights and freedoms of the 'User' which require protection of personal data. This shall not apply to processing carried out by 'regulatory authorities' in the performance of their tasks.
cu_p_691: Section 1798.105 (b) An 'Automotive Dealer' that collects personal information about 'Vehicle Owners' shall disclose, pursuant to subparagraph (A) of paragraph (5) of subdivision (a) of Section 1798.130, the 'Vehicle Owner’s' rights to request the deletion of the 'Vehicle Owner’s' personal information. Section 1798.130 (a) the 'Automotive Dealer' shall: (5) Disclose the following information in its online privacy policy or policies if the business has an online privacy policy or policies and in any California-specific description of consumers’ privacy rights, or if the business does not maintain those policies, on its Internet Web site, and update that information at least once every 12 months: (A) A description of a 'Vehicle Owner’s' rights, which shall explicitly inform a 'Vehicle Owner' that they have the following rights, and provide one or more designated methods for submitting requests: Right to Know, Right to Access, Right to Opt-Out of Sale/Sharing.
cu_p_692: Section 1798.105 (b) A 'Healthcare Provider' that collects personal information about 'Patients' shall disclose, pursuant to subparagraph (A) of paragraph (5) of subdivision (a) of Section 1798.130, the 'Patient’s' rights to request the deletion of the 'Patient’s' personal information. Section 1798.130 (a) the 'Healthcare Provider' shall: (5) Disclose the following information in its online privacy policy or policies if the business has an online privacy policy or policies and in any California-specific description of consumers’ privacy rights, or if the business does not maintain those policies, on its Internet Web site, and update that information at least once every 12 months: (A) A description of a 'Patient’s' rights, which shall explicitly inform a 'Patient' that they have the following rights, and provide one or more designated methods for submitting requests: Right to Know, Right to Access, Right to Opt-Out of Sale/Sharing.
cu_p_693: Section 1798.105 (b) A 'Retail E-commerce' business that collects personal information about 'Customers' shall disclose, pursuant to subparagraph (A) of paragraph (5) of subdivision (a) of Section 1798.130, the 'Customer’s' rights to request the deletion of the 'Customer’s' personal information. Section 1798.130 (a) the 'Retail E-commerce' business shall: (5) Disclose the following information in its online privacy policy or policies if the business has an online privacy policy or policies and in any California-specific description of consumers’ privacy rights, or if the business does not maintain those policies, on its Internet Web site, and update that information at least once every 12 months: (A) A description of a 'Customer’s' rights, which shall explicitly inform a 'Customer' that they have the following rights, and provide one or more designated methods for submitting requests: Right to Know, Right to Access, Right to Opt-Out of Sale/Sharing.
cu_p_694: Section 1798.105 (b) A 'Gaming Company' that collects personal information about 'Players' shall disclose, pursuant to subparagraph (A) of paragraph (5) of subdivision (a) of Section 1798.130, the 'Player’s' rights to request the deletion of the 'Player’s' personal information. Section 1798.130 (a) the 'Gaming Company' shall: (5) Disclose the following information in its online privacy policy or policies if the business has an online privacy policy or policies and in any California-specific description of consumers’ privacy rights, or if the business does not maintain those policies, on its Internet Web site, and update that information at least once every 12 months: (A) A description of a 'Player’s' rights, which shall explicitly inform a 'Player' that they have the following rights, and provide one or more designated methods for submitting requests: Right to Know, Right to Access, Right to Opt-Out of Sale/Sharing.
cu_p_695: Section 1798.105 (b) A 'Streaming Service Provider' that collects personal information about 'Subscribers' shall disclose, pursuant to subparagraph (A) of paragraph (5) of subdivision (a) of Section 1798.130, the 'Subscriber’s' rights to request the deletion of the 'Subscriber’s' personal information. Section 1798.130 (a) the 'Streaming Service Provider' shall: (5) Disclose the following information in its online privacy policy or policies if the business has an online privacy policy or policies and in any California-specific description of consumers’ privacy rights, or if the business does not maintain those policies, on its Internet Web site, and update that information at least once every 12 months: (A) A description of a 'Subscriber’s' rights, which shall explicitly inform a 'Subscriber' that they have the following rights, and provide one or more designated methods for submitting requests: Right to Know, Right to Access, Right to Opt-Out of Sale/Sharing.
cu_p_696: Section 1798.120 (a) A 'User' shall have the right, at any time, to direct a 'Social Media Platform' that sells personal information about the 'User' to 'Data Brokers' not to sell the 'User’s' personal information. This right may be referred to as the right to opt out. (d) Notwithstanding subdivision (a), a 'Social Media Platform' shall not sell the personal information of 'Users' if the business has actual knowledge that the 'User' is less than 16 years of age, unless the 'User', in the case of 'Users' between 13 and 16 years of age, or the 'User’s' parent or guardian, in the case of 'Users' who are less than 13 years of age, has affirmatively authorized the sale of the 'User’s' personal information. A 'Social Media Platform' that willfully disregards the 'User’s' age shall be deemed to have had actual knowledge of the 'User’s' age. This right may be referred to as the 'right to opt in.'
cu_p_697: Section 1798.120 (a) A 'Member' shall have the right, at any time, to direct a 'Retailer' that sells personal information about the 'Member' to 'Marketing Partners' not to sell the 'Member’s' personal information. This right may be referred to as the right to opt out. (d) Notwithstanding subdivision (a), a 'Retailer' shall not sell the personal information of 'Members' if the business has actual knowledge that the 'Member' is less than 16 years of age, unless the 'Member', in the case of 'Members' between 13 and 16 years of age, or the 'Member’s' parent or guardian, in the case of 'Members' who are less than 13 years of age, has affirmatively authorized the sale of the 'Member’s' personal information. A 'Retailer' that willfully disregards the 'Member’s' age shall be deemed to have had actual knowledge of the 'Member’s' age. This right may be referred to as the 'right to opt in.'
cu_p_698: Section 1798.120 (a) A 'Subscriber' shall have the right, at any time, to direct an 'Online Magazine' that sells personal information about the 'Subscriber' to 'Third-Party Publishers' not to sell the 'Subscriber’s' personal information. This right may be referred to as the right to opt out. (d) Notwithstanding subdivision (a), an 'Online Magazine' shall not sell the personal information of 'Subscribers' if the business has actual knowledge that the 'Subscriber' is less than 16 years of age, unless the 'Subscriber', in the case of 'Subscribers' between 13 and 16 years of age, or the 'Subscriber’s' parent or guardian, in the case of 'Subscribers' who are less than 13 years of age, has affirmatively authorized the sale of the 'Subscriber’s' personal information. An 'Online Magazine' that willfully disregards the 'Subscriber’s' age shall be deemed to have had actual knowledge of the 'Subscriber’s' age. This right may be referred to as the 'right to opt in.'
cu_p_699: Section 1798.120 (a) A 'Traveler' shall have the right, at any time, to direct an 'Online Travel Agency' that sells personal information about the 'Traveler' to 'Ad Networks' not to sell the 'Traveler’s' personal information. This right may be referred to as the right to opt out. (d) Notwithstanding subdivision (a), an 'Online Travel Agency' shall not sell the personal information of 'Travelers' if the business has actual knowledge that the 'Traveler' is less than 16 years of age, unless the 'Traveler', in the case of 'Travelers' between 13 and 16 years of age, or the 'Traveler’s' parent or guardian, in the case of 'Travelers' who are less than 13 years of age, has affirmatively authorized the sale of the 'Traveler’s' personal information. An 'Online Travel Agency' that willfully disregards the 'Traveler’s' age shall be deemed to have had actual knowledge of the 'Traveler’s' age. This right may be referred to as the 'right to opt in.'
cu_p_700: Section 1798.120 (a) A 'Viewer' shall have the right, at any time, to direct a 'Video Streaming Platform' that sells personal information about the 'Viewer' to 'Content Delivery Networks' not to sell the 'Viewer’s' personal information. This right may be referred to as the right to opt out. (d) Notwithstanding subdivision (a), a 'Video Streaming Platform' shall not sell the personal information of 'Viewers' if the business has actual knowledge that the 'Viewer' is less than 16 years of age, unless the 'Viewer', in the case of 'Viewers' between 13 and 16 years of age, or the 'Viewer’s' parent or guardian, in the case of 'Viewers' who are less than 13 years of age, has affirmatively authorized the sale of the 'Viewer’s' personal information. A 'Video Streaming Platform' that willfully disregards the 'Viewer’s' age shall be deemed to have had actual knowledge of the 'Viewer’s' age. This right may be referred to as the 'right to opt in.'
cu_p_701: Article 45 A 'Data Asset Holder' has the right to access and copy their 'data product' from a 'Data Trading Platform', except under the circumstances stipulated in Article 18 of this Law. If a 'Data Asset Holder' requests to access or copy their 'data product', the 'Data Trading Platform' shall provide it promptly. If a 'Data Asset Holder' requests to transfer their 'data product' to another 'Data Service Provider' they designate, and the conditions stipulated by the state data administration department are met, the 'Data Trading Platform' shall provide a means for the transfer. Article 18 If a 'Data Trading Platform' processes 'data products' under circumstances where laws or administrative regulations require confidentiality or do not require notification, it may not inform the 'Data Asset Holder' of the matters stipulated in the first paragraph of the preceding article.
cu_p_702: Article 45 A 'Vehicle Owner' has the right to access and copy their 'vehicle mortgage information' from an 'Auto Finance Company', except under the circumstances stipulated in Article 18 of this Law. If a 'Vehicle Owner' requests to access or copy their 'vehicle mortgage information', the 'Auto Finance Company' shall provide it promptly. If a 'Vehicle Owner' requests to transfer their 'vehicle mortgage information' to another 'Commercial Bank' they designate, and the conditions stipulated by the state financial regulatory department are met, the 'Auto Finance Company' shall provide a means for the transfer. Article 18 If an 'Auto Finance Company' processes 'vehicle mortgage information' under circumstances where laws or administrative regulations require confidentiality or do not require notification, it may not inform the 'Vehicle Owner' of the matters stipulated in the first paragraph of the preceding article.
cu_p_703: Article 45 A 'Policyholder' has the right to access and copy their 'insurance contract information' from an 'Insurance Company', except under the circumstances stipulated in Article 18 of this Law. If a 'Policyholder' requests to access or copy their 'insurance contract information', the 'Insurance Company' shall provide it promptly. If a 'Policyholder' requests to transfer their 'insurance contract information' to another 'Insurance Brokerage Firm' they designate, and the conditions stipulated by the state insurance supervisory and administrative department are met, the 'Insurance Company' shall provide a means for the transfer. Article 18 If an 'Insurance Company' processes 'insurance contract information' under circumstances where laws or administrative regulations require confidentiality or do not require notification, it may not inform the 'Policyholder' of the matters stipulated in the first paragraph of the preceding article.
cu_p_704: Article 45 An 'Enterprise' has the right to access and copy its 'credit report' from a 'Credit Reporting Agency', except under the circumstances stipulated in Article 18 of this Law. If an 'Enterprise' requests to access or copy its 'credit report', the 'Credit Reporting Agency' shall provide it promptly. If an 'Enterprise' requests to transfer its 'credit report' to another 'Financial Institution' it designates, and the conditions stipulated by the state credit industry administrative department are met, the 'Credit Reporting Agency' shall provide a means for the transfer. Article 18 If a 'Credit Reporting Agency' processes 'credit reports' under circumstances where laws or administrative regulations require confidentiality or do not require notification, it may not inform the 'Enterprise' of the matters stipulated in the first paragraph of the preceding article.
cu_p_705: Article 45 An 'Author' has the right to access and copy their 'work copyright information' from a 'Digital Publishing Platform', except under the circumstances stipulated in Article 18 of this Law. If an 'Author' requests to access or copy their 'work copyright information', the 'Digital Publishing Platform' shall provide it promptly. If an 'Author' requests to transfer their 'work copyright information' to another 'Copyright Agency' they designate, and the conditions stipulated by the state copyright administration department are met, the 'Digital Publishing Platform' shall provide a means for the transfer. Article 18 If a 'Digital Publishing Platform' processes 'work copyright information' under circumstances where laws or administrative regulations require confidentiality or do not require notification, it may not inform the 'Author' of the matters stipulated in the first paragraph of the preceding article.
cu_p_706: Article 53 A 'Component Supplier' outside the territory of the 'Catena-X Data Space' as stipulated in the second paragraph of Article 3 of this Law, shall establish a dedicated entity or appoint a representative within the 'Catena-X China Node' to handle matters related to 'automotive supply chain data' protection, and shall report the name of the entity or the name and contact information of the representative to the department responsible for 'industrial data' protection. Article 3 This Law also applies to activities of processing 'production data' of 'domestic Chinese automotive manufacturers' outside the territory of the 'Catena-X Data Space' if one of the following circumstances exists: (2) for the purpose of analyzing and evaluating the production efficiency of 'domestic automotive manufacturers'.
cu_p_707: Article 53 A 'Hedge Fund' outside the territory of the 'International Financial Data Network' as stipulated in the second paragraph of Article 3 of this Law, shall establish a dedicated entity or appoint a representative within 'mainland China' to handle matters related to 'financial transaction data' protection, and shall report the name of the entity or the name and contact information of the representative to the department responsible for 'financial information' protection. Article 3 This Law also applies to activities of processing 'transaction behavior data' of 'domestic Chinese investors' outside the territory of the 'International Financial Data Network' if one of the following circumstances exists: (2) for the purpose of analyzing and evaluating the investment behavior of 'domestic investors'.
cu_p_708: Article 53 A 'Pharmaceutical Company' outside the territory of the 'Global Clinical Trial Data Platform' as stipulated in the second paragraph of Article 3 of this Law, shall establish a dedicated entity or appoint a representative within 'mainland China' to handle matters related to 'clinical trial data' protection, and shall report the name of the entity or the name and contact information of the representative to the department responsible for 'human genetic resources' protection. Article 3 This Law also applies to activities of processing 'health data' of 'domestic Chinese trial subjects' outside the territory of the 'Global Clinical Trial Data Platform' if one of the following circumstances exists: (2) for the purpose of analyzing and evaluating the physiological responses of 'domestic trial subjects'.
cu_p_709: Article 53 An 'Overseas Retailer' outside the territory of the 'Cross-border E-commerce Data Sharing Alliance' as stipulated in the second paragraph of Article 3 of this Law, shall establish a dedicated entity or appoint a representative within 'mainland China' to handle matters related to 'consumer shopping data' protection, and shall report the name of the entity or the name and contact information of the representative to the department responsible for 'consumer rights' protection. Article 3 This Law also applies to activities of processing 'shopping preference data' of 'domestic Chinese consumers' outside the territory of the 'Cross-border E-commerce Data Sharing Alliance' if one of the following circumstances exists: (2) for the purpose of analyzing and evaluating the purchasing behavior of 'domestic consumers'.
cu_p_710: Article 53 A 'Foreign Airline' outside the territory of the 'International Aviation Data Exchange Center' as stipulated in the second paragraph of Article 3 of this Law, shall establish a dedicated entity or appoint a representative within 'mainland China' to handle matters related to 'flight operations data' protection, and shall report the name of the entity or the name and contact information of the representative to the department responsible for 'civil aviation information' protection. Article 3 This Law also applies to activities of processing 'travel data' of 'domestic Chinese passengers' outside the territory of the 'International Aviation Data Exchange Center' if one of the following circumstances exists: (2) for the purpose of analyzing and evaluating the travel patterns of 'domestic passengers'.
cu_p_711: Article 46 A 'mining company' that provides important data on the 'critical mineral supply chain' to a recipient outside the territory in violation of Article 31 of this Law shall be ordered to make corrections and given a warning by the 'natural resources authority', and may be fined not less than 100,000 yuan but not more than 1 million yuan, and the directly responsible person in charge and other directly liable persons may be fined not less than 10,000 yuan but not more than 100,000 yuan; if the circumstances are serious, a fine of not less than 1 million yuan but not more than 10 million yuan shall be imposed, and it may be ordered to suspend relevant business, cease operations for rectification, or have its relevant business permit or business license revoked, and the directly responsible person in charge and other directly liable persons shall be fined not less than 100,000 yuan but not more than 1 million yuan. Article 31 The security management for the outbound transfer of important 'power grid operation' data collected and generated during operations within the territory of the People's Republic of China by operators of critical information infrastructure in the 'energy sector' shall be governed by the provisions of the Cybersecurity Law of the People's Republic of China; the measures for the security management of outbound transfers of important 'oil and gas pipeline network' data collected and generated during operations within the territory of the People's Republic of China by other data processors shall be formulated by the 'National Energy Administration' in conjunction with the relevant departments of the State Council.
cu_p_712: Article 46 A 'gene sequencing company' that provides important 'biogene' data to a recipient outside the territory in violation of Article 31 of this Law shall be ordered to make corrections and given a warning by the 'science and technology authority', and may be fined not less than 100,000 yuan but not more than 1 million yuan, and the directly responsible person in charge and other directly liable persons may be fined not less than 10,000 yuan but not more than 100,000 yuan; if the circumstances are serious, a fine of not less than 1 million yuan but not more than 10 million yuan shall be imposed, and it may be ordered to suspend relevant business, cease operations for rectification, or have its relevant business permit or business license revoked, and the directly responsible person in charge and other directly liable persons shall be fined not less than 100,000 yuan but not more than 1 million yuan. Article 31 The security management for the outbound transfer of important 'human genetic resources' data collected and generated during operations within the territory of the People's Republic of China by operators of critical information infrastructure for 'human genetic resources information' shall be governed by the provisions of the Regulations of the People's Republic of China on the Management of Human Genetic Resources; the measures for the security management of outbound transfers of important 'biosample' data collected and generated during operations within the territory of the People's Republic of China by other data processors shall be formulated by the 'state science and technology administrative department' in conjunction with the relevant departments of the State Council.
cu_p_713: Article 46 A 'securities firm' that provides important 'financial market' data to a recipient outside the territory in violation of Article 31 of this Law shall be ordered to make corrections and given a warning by the 'financial regulatory authority', and may be fined not less than 100,000 yuan but not more than 1 million yuan, and the directly responsible person in charge and other directly liable persons may be fined not less than 10,000 yuan but not more than 100,000 yuan; if the circumstances are serious, a fine of not less than 1 million yuan but not more than 10 million yuan shall be imposed, and it may be ordered to suspend relevant business, cease operations for rectification, or have its relevant business permit or business license revoked, and the directly responsible person in charge and other directly liable persons shall be fined not less than 100,000 yuan but not more than 1 million yuan. Article 31 The security management for the outbound transfer of important 'cross-border payment' data collected and generated during operations within the territory of the People's Republic of China by operators of critical information infrastructure in the 'financial industry' shall be governed by the provisions of the Law of the People's Republic of China on the People's Bank of China; the measures for the security management of outbound transfers of important 'securities trading' data collected and generated during operations within the territory of the People's Republic of China by other data processors shall be formulated by the 'National Administration of Financial Regulation' in conjunction with the relevant departments of the State Council.
